test_df = pd.read_csv('../input/titanic/test.csv')
train_columns = train_df.columns.to_list()

tmp = list(set(train_columns) - set(test_columns))

source.6271421e:
import pandas as pd
from autogluon.tabular import TabularDataset, TabularPredictor

train= TabularDataset('../input/titanic/train.csv')
test = TabularDataset('../input/titanic/test.csv')

# Added the following 6 lines of code
train_df = pd.read_csv('../input/titanic/train.csv')
test_df = pd.read_csv('../input/titanic/test.csv')
train_columns = train_df.columns.to_list()
test_columns = test_df.columns.to_list()
tmp = list(set(train_columns) - set(test_columns))
label = tmp[0]

# No need for the following code
# label='Survived'
time_limit=60
predictor = TabularPredictor(label=label).fit(train, time_limit=time_limit)

submission = pd.read_csv('../input/titanic/gender_submission.csv')
submission[label] = predictor.predict(test)
submission.to_csv('submission.csv', index=False)
submission.head()
source.1f52d18b:
import pandas as pd

# function
def identify_larget_label_name(train_csv_pass, test_csv_pass):
    train_df = pd.read_csv(train_csv_pass)
    test_df = pd.read_csv(test_csv_pass)
    train_columns = train_df.columns.to_list()
    test_columns = test_df.columns.to_list()
    tmp = list(set(train_columns) - set(test_columns))
    label = tmp[0]
    return label

# example of use
train_csv_pass = '../input/titanic/train.csv'
test_csv_pass = '../input/titanic/test.csv'
label = identify_larget_label_name(train_csv_pass, test_csv_pass)

print(label)
source.62248d0f:
## Abstract

Specific extraction of target label name from the difference between training data and test data columns. I think that it can be used when you want to create a benchmark quickly in a competition with a simple structure such as Titanic.
